channel.title: Newest Python PEPs
channel.description: Newest Python Enhancement Proposals (PEPs) - Information on new language features, and some meta-information like release procedure and schedules.

item.title: PEP 695: Type Parameter Syntax
item.description: This PEP specifies an improved syntax for specifying type parameters within a generic class, function, or type alias. It also introduces a new statement for declaring type aliases.
item.author: Eric Traut (erictr at microsoft.com)

item.title: PEP 694: Upload 2.0 API for Python Package Repositories
item.description: There is currently no standardized API for uploading files to a Python package repository such as PyPI. Instead, everyone has been forced to reverse engineer the non-standard API from PyPI.
item.author: Donald Stufft (donald@stufft.io)

item.title: PEP 692: Using TypedDict for more precise \*\*kwargs typing
item.description: Currently **kwargs can be type hinted as long as all of the keyword arguments specified by them are of the same type. However, that behaviour can be very limiting. Therefore, in this PEP we propose a new way to enable more precise **kwargs typing. The new approach revolves around using TypedDict to type **kwargs that comprise keyword arguments of different types. It also involves introducing a grammar change and a new dunder __unpack__.
item.author: Franek Magiera (framagie@gmail.com)

item.title: PEP 693: Python 3.12 Release Schedule
item.description: This document describes the development and release schedule for Python 3.12. The schedule primarily concerns itself with PEP-sized items.
item.author: Thomas Wouters (thomas@python.org)

item.title: PEP 691: JSON-based Simple API for Python Package Indexes
item.description: The "Simple Repository API" that was defined in PEP 503 (and was in use much longer than that) has served us reasonably well for a very long time. However, the reliance on using HTML as the data exchange mechanism has several shortcomings.
item.author: Donald Stufft (donald@stufft.io)

item.title: PEP 690: Lazy Imports
item.description: This PEP proposes a feature to transparently defer the execution of imported modules until the moment when an imported object is first used. Since Python programs commonly import many more modules than a single invocation of the program is likely to use in practice, lazy imports can greatly reduce the overall number of modules loaded, improving startup time and memory usage. Lazy imports also mostly eliminate the risk of import cycles.
item.author: Germán Méndez Bravo (german.mb@gmail.com), Carl Meyer (carl@oddbird.net)

item.title: PEP 688: Making the buffer protocol accessible in Python
item.description: This PEP proposes a mechanism for Python code to inspect whether a type supports the C-level buffer protocol. This allows type checkers to evaluate whether objects implement the protocol.
item.author: Jelle Zijlstra (jelle.zijlstra@gmail.com)

item.title: PEP 689: Unstable C API tier
item.description: Some functions and types of the C-API are designated unstable, meaning that they will not change in patch (bugfix/security) releases, but may change between minor releases (e.g. between 3.11 and 3.12) without deprecation warnings.
item.author: Petr Viktorin (encukou@gmail.com)

item.title: PEP 687: Isolating modules in the standard library
item.description: Extensions in the standard library will be converted to multi-phase initialization (PEP 489) and where possible, all state will be stored on module objects rather than in process-global variables.
item.author: Erlend Egeberg Aasland (erlend.aasland@protonmail.com), Petr Viktorin (encukou@gmail.com)

item.title: PEP 686: Make UTF-8 mode default
item.description: This PEP proposes enabling UTF-8 mode by default.
item.author: Inada Naoki (songofacandy@gmail.com)
